newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ireland's McCreevy - a straight-talking finance man.
newsitem.headline: Ireland's McCreevy - a straight-talking finance man.

text.p: Charlie McCreevy, tipped as Finance Minister if Fianna Fail and its Progressive Democrat allies win Friday's Irish election, is a rough diamond known for no-nonsense talking and contempt for government overspending.

The combative 47-year-old Kildare accountant is a key aspirant for the enviable task of presiding over an Irish economic boom, low inflation, abundant coffers and more room to manoeuvre than for the past decade or more.
He has been unwavering in his commitment, over the years, to cut government spending, reduce taxes and slash the national debt of 30 billion Irish pounds ($44.4 billion).

McCreevy says that if he is made Finance Minister government spending will not increase above the inflation rate plus 2.0 percent, a total spend of four percent against the current government's eight percent.
"You have to decide what spending will be and then stick to it," McCreevy told Reuters.

He has been indefatigable in his criticism of the current government's "spending spree," warning that when the economy dubbed the "Celtic Tiger" runs out of steam it will be impossible to reduce spending.
His outspoken manner has landed McCreevy in trouble more than once.

As Fianna Fail spokesman on finance, he blotted his copybook in January by using his own party's errors to highlight weaknesses in the budget of the three-party centre-left coalition government Fianna Fail hopes to dislodge.
In off-the-cuff comments McCreevy pointed to an attempt by Fianna Fail "to spend its way out of a crisis in 1977", which, he confessed, had not worked. It was seen as a sloppy "own goal."
Equally, he said current government strategy of increasing spending while cutting taxes, would also fail.

In 1982, McCreevy found himself briefly expelled from Fianna Fail for his persistent demands for fiscal rectitude which were seen as a criticism of the party leadership under former Prime Minister Charles Haughey.

He reserves much of his anger, which has a genuinely sharp edge, for the Labour Party of Dick Spring, which pulled out of a coalition government with Fianna Fail in 1994 and switched its support to John Bruton's Fine Gael party.
Spring, whose party has held the balance of power in recent governments, has ruled out any coalition with Fianna Fail.
McCreevy is scathing about Spring, a man Fianna Fail has drubbed "Tricky Dicky" and "Chicken Dick" since 1994.
"There's no point ruling out Fianna Fail and Labour as a coalition, that is the bullshit principle of Irish politics," McCreevy told Irish media.
While Fianna Fail leader Bertie Ahern has voiced his commitment to Ireland joining European Monetary Union, McCreevy is not so convinced.
"Lets be honest about it, if Britain is staying out there are going to be problems," he told the Irish Times in an interview in April.
"Even though we have reduced our dependence on trade with Britain, it still is and always will be, our major trading partner."
He has weathered a disappointingly chequered 20 years in politics sometimes favoured, sometimes shunned, often hampered by his lack of adherence to "club rules".
A racing enthusiast, McCreevy backed a hunch in 1991 and supported the challenger, Albert Reynolds, for the leadership, a move which rescued him from a decade of backbench wrangling.
When Reynolds became Prime Minister he rewarded him with the post of minister for Social Welfare.
But once again McCreevy sparked controversy when he introduced a set of proposals later dubbed the "dirty dozen" which recommended highly unpopular cuts in welfare payments and benefits.

The fall of Albert Reynolds' Fianna Fail/Labour coalition in 1994 and the accession of Bertie Ahern as a "consensus" party leader resulted in a surprise promotion for McCreevy to Fianna Fail's spokesman on finance.
The previous holder of the position was Fianna Fail leader Bertie Ahern, who once boasted that he had put government finances in the best shape for a generation.
